text: Friday, 14 November 1986 Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers. AUSTRALIA CARD BILL 1986 Second Reading Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Dr Blewett: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: Unknown
text: 1 listened last night to the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), who preceded me in the debate, and his litany of those who are opposed to the introduction of the Australia Card. To balance the record, I will list a few people who are in favour of it: Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Eric Myer of the Business Council of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Australia, and even our old mate Andrew Hay, who told the National Taxation Summit that it could playa key role in coming to grips with social security fraud. The Law Council of Australia supports it, as do the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the Australian Society of Accountants. Let me quote from the Returned Services League national newsletter of June 1986: The RSL congratulates the Government for recognising the need for a compulsory photographic identification card for all Australians. The list of those who support it goes on. There are groups as diverse as the Queensland Chamber of Fresh Fruit and Vegetables, professors of economics and, indeed, trade unions. I could refer to quotes which show that at various times support has been given by the New South Wales Leader of the Opposition, the President of the Victorian Branch of the Liberal Party, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) and the shadow spokesman for social security. Of course, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has strongly advocated it at various times, as has the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt). Indeed, at times, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has supported it. Mr Keogh-Who is that?

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: Unknown
text: At the moment I believe it is the honourable member for Bennelong, but the position is very shaky, I am told. There is a difference of only two in the numbers this morning, I am told. Senator Janine Haines supported it in her statement to the National Tax Summit. Support has been given by the shadow Minister for Science in the Senate. All my colleagues on this side of the House support this legislation with one voice. Indeed, within my own family, even my pensioner mum and dad support this legislation. Of course, thousands and thousands of ordinary Australians support it because they are sick and tired of the cheats who are ripping off the system. I have noticed in the last two weeks in one of the New South Wales papersthe Sun-Herald, I think-that the honourable member for Macquarie has received quite a lot of coverage in talking about various proposals to tighten up the social security system and about fraud. After making those statements in the last two issues of the Sun-Herald, how could he argue in the House last night against the Australia Card? In the four years during which I have been a member of parliament the one thing I have learned to admire is the effrontery of those who sit opposite, the people who are now declaring themselves to be on the side of tax evaders. The debate in which we have engaged has been wide ranging and speakers on this side of the House have been answering the red herrings that have been put up by the Opposition and what red herrings they have been. Of course, this will not stop Opposition members running around Australia trying to scare people about this legislation. We saw this happen with the assets test, the fringe benefits tax and the human rights Bill. Opposition members should read the editorials in yesterday'S newspapers-the Australian, the Sydney Morning Herald, the Canberra Times or the Australian Financial Review. Given what commentators are saying in the papers and the Opposition's performance in this chamber, how long can the honourable  before he makes his challenge. Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: Unknown
text: Even I could not attempt to unravel the problems in the Liberal Party. It is interesting that the honourable member for Bennelong has finally discovered the cash economy. It is a pity he did not discover it during the time he had charge of the Treasury. The Melbourne Age of 26 March 1986 said about the cash economy: The Australian Retailers Association claimed that cardthe Australia Cardwould go a long way towards eliminating the cash economy once and for all! We on this side of the House know about the cash economy and we are doing something about it. The main offenders in the cash economy are builders, who are conducting the strongest campaign against this legislation, the real estate business and the Opposition. What are they opposing? They are opposing a government measure to bring fairness and equity into our system and to stop fraud for which the honest taxpayer is paying to the tune of millions of dollars each year. That is what they are opposing. What is the Opposition offering? We on this side of the House and the Australian people do not know what it is offering because it will not release any details of its policies. However, we do know that the Opposition has abandoned any claims to being serious about tackling tax evasion and avoidance and social welfare fraud in Australia. The Australian people know it and they will be reminded of it day after day leading up to the next election. The Government will remind them of the Opposition's record and how it opposed this measure which would tackle tax evasion and avoidance and social welfare fraud in Australia. We have listened to the claims of the Opposition about the Australia Card being an attack on civil liberties. The Australia Card program proposed by the Hawke Labor Government is part of a package which will put in place the most comprehensive safeguards for privacy ever seen in this country. From what has been said by honourable members opposite, one would think that no other country had a national identification system. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) yesterday gave us a list of the countries which have such a system. I might say that countries with civil liberties that we can only envy have national identification schemes. The Opposition is cynically distorting the language of genuine civil libertarians. It is claiming that it is a citizen's basic right to be able to defraud the community, either through not paying his or her fair share of tax or through cheating the social security system. I listened last night to the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) telling us how honest every citizen was and that there was very little fraud. I would agree with him that the average Australian citizen is honest. But the Opposition, especially members of the National Party of the Australia, have been running around the country year in and year out talking about fraud and how fraud has to be controlled. Who has been screaming the loudest for the Government to control this fraud? Who has been most critical of government because of supposed overpayments and fraud cheats? It has been members of the National Party. Let us have a look at some of the statements that have been made on this matter. On 8 June 1985 the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the shadow Minister for Social Security, said: The introduction of a national identification system, using ID cards, offered benefits to the Australian people, which outweighed any civil liberties considerations. He went on: Another majority benefit would be a reduction of fraud affecting Government outlays, especially social welfare payments. On 6 November 1985 the honourable member for Richmond said: Those people who have ripped off the welfare system, especially those whose names are known, must not be allowed to escape scot free. On 23 May 1986 he said: It's time to toughen up for the sake of the taxpayers and genuine people looking for work. I might say that 12 months ago the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) was widely reported in my electorate as being in favour of the Australia Card. Articles appeared in the Highlands Post, the Southern Highlands News, the Shoalhaven and Nowra News, the South Coast Register and many other publications with comments from him about how he was in favour of the Australia Card. But, for good measure, he gave the Hawke Government a service because he thought that we would not go ahead with the Australia Card. But what has happened to the honourable member for Gilmore? He has been very quiet. I keep asking him in the local papers to state where he stands and whether he has the same view that he put 12 months ago. But the honourable member for Gilmore has been muzzled by his own party because he supports the introduction of the Australia Card. If some 12 months ago the honourable member was so much in support of the Australia Card, will he cross the floor and vote with this side, which really would be the only honourable thing for him to do? The Opposition has been very critical of this Government about this legislation. But what is it proposing? Nothing would come anywhere near the Australia Card for effectiveness in tackling the problem of tax and welfare cheats. This Government is the first Federal Government in Australia's history to do anything about fraud and tax cheats. Why is it that the Opposition attempts to deny the Government the very instrument which would most effectively restore fairness and equity to the tax and welfare system? I would be delighted to fight an election on the issue of the Australia Card so that the people of Australia could express their view on this Government, which is tackling fraud and tax avoidance, and on the Opposition, which continues to support these tax avoiders and welfare cheats. Why should the ordinary, decent taxpayer of Throsby support tax avoidance, fraud and cheats? The ordinary pay as you earn worker of Throsby has had enough. The taxpayers of my electorate are rightly demanding that the Government do something. They have seen the Opposition, after years on the Treasury benches doing nothing, now supporting fraud and welfare cheats. The Australian public will not be deceived by the hollow rhetoric of the Opposition members. They have no effective alternative to the Australia Card. They are unconvincing grandstanders who prefer to allow tax evasion and welfare fraud to continue unabated rather than see this Government take effective action to tackle these scourges. We on this side of the House are serious about cutting the crooks out of the social security system and the Australia Card will be the key component in our scrutinisation strategy. As I said, those on the Opposition benches have no effective alternative to the Australia Card. They are unconvincing grandstanders. I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: Unknown
text: Most honourable members have attempted to justify their position in supporting the Australian identity card by quoting from a statement. I made in June last year. The honourable member who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), sought to shield behind a statement that I made last year in giving support to this legislation. It is true that I made a statement last year in good faith because I had what proved to be a simplistic view that such a system would stamp out social security and certain types of tax fraud. It was a simplistic view. It is a simplistic view that a lot of people probably still hold throughout Australia. I think most of us have been concerned with the extent of fraud that has been going on, and a great deal of it has been going on in the cash economy. But I am not convinced that this particular card is going to stamp out that type of fraud. A withholding tax may, but no one can wipeout fraud generally in the community. It would be like trying to wipe out prostitution. If anybody thinks that this card is going to wipe out fraud, he is crazy. Following the majority findings of the joint and all-party committee of inquiry against the Australian identity card system I changed my views. Indeed a lot of people changed their views because there was a very extensive inquiry held by representatives of every political party of this Parliament. It produced a very comprehensive report and the members of that inquiry went into extensive study of the situation. As a result of having read that report and having talked to the members of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card I came to the view that it was a very extensive intrusion into the privacy of people without really coming to grips with the problem that this legislation has set out to solve. As a consequence of this I issued a statement on 12 June of this year, but nobody quotes this statement; instead they choose only to quote a statement. I made over 12 months ago. Mr MCGauran-You have been misrepresented.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: Unknown
text: No, I have not been misrepresented, because last year I sincerely held that view. I do not for one moment criticise those members of the Australian Labor Party who held a view different from mine last year. Members of the Australian Labor Party, and a great number of them, in good faith were opposed to this identity card because they were concerned about civil liberties. But the overwhelming arguments that have been put to them in the Caucus apparently have been sufficient to change their view. We live in a democratic society where we are supposed to listen to reason, where we are supposed to debate and argue issues. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is probably one person who changes his mind more than most in this country. Only a few weeks ago he was talking about mining in the Kakadu National Park. What is he saying today? Today he is talking about legal action against Geopeko, so he has changed his mind. Only a week or so ago there was not to be logging in the Tasmanian national parks, but because of the discussions between the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Tasmanian Minister I understand logging will continue. So there is a change of mind. Facts often have a big influence on rational thinking and ultimate decisions. Australians have the biggest task. They will have to assess whether it is right and proper to have an identity card making them, as individuals, the victims of close scrutiny. The dealings and activities of each and everyone of us will be registered on microfilm that will become the property of the state. The individual is not the property of the state. It is against that background that I certainly changed my view because I could see that there would be no real cost benefit in the proposed solution to the problem. On June 12 this year I said: The national identity card proposed by the Hawke Government will not be effective in controlling social security fraud, tax evasion or illegal immigrants. In fact, in the United States a major problem had become the production of fraudulent ID cards. I was initially in favour of the proposal . . . but after a close study . . . I am now convinced it is not the way to go. When I said that, I believed that there was still a possibility that the Government would not ultimately come down with a final decision on this matter because there were people in the Labor Party who were concerned about it. I also said that the card would cost $2 billion over the next 10 years and would require the employment of an extra 2,150 public servants to administer !t. I said that every two years-but I was wrong In this respect; I think it is every four or five years-every Australian would need to be rephotographed for a new card. I continued: The Australia card will not be cost effective. The savings and the result of introducing the card will not justify its cost. A much more cost effective solution involves the Department of Social Security carrying out more in the field of checks and to enforce the work test for benefits and the Taxation Office using a high integrity tax file number. More emphasis on the effective use of the present mechanisms to stop cheats rather than creating another massive bureaucracy is the sensible road to take. I seek leave to table a copy of what I said in June this year. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: Unknown
text: Let nobody else go running around talking about what I said in June last year. We can all look back to see what we said this year, last year, 10 years ago. I make no apology-it is not a confession at all. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is a very intelligent man. He is a Rhodes scholar and I would have thought that a man of his integrity and intelligence would have changed his mind from time to time. If he has not he must have got his Rhodes scholarship by default. I enter this debate only briefly to put the record straight. But since the Bill was introduced I have strengthened my opposition to this outrageously intrusive legislation which makes every Australia the compliant victim and the property of the Commonwealth bureaucracy in the form of a humble servant of the state. It is obnoxious legislation. It is intrusive of the fundamental rights of the individual. It changes the fundamental relationship between the individual and the state and it reeks of the type of identification system one could expect to find in a totalitarian state. It does so at great cost to the taxpaying citizens, without necessarily achieving the abolition of fraud. Even the Minister said earlier: 'Nobody says it is going to stop fraud'. This massive Bill of 130 pages provides for the careful construction of an information network and profile of each individual, giving government agencies unprecedented access to detailed information about each Australian citizen. It is an insidious violation of individual privacy. The Government, in its totalitarian zeal-I say that deliberately because there is a totalitarian zeal about this-has attempted to impose a Bill of Rights defining the rights it is prepared to extend to its citizens. This was supposed to be a free country. Now it seeks to inflict another imposition on individual rights. The Government has ignored the findings of its Joint Committee and the views of people within its own ranks. The 130 pages in the Bill contain a maze of requirements which effectively will make it essential for individuals to carry their card at all times. The Government will force people to make their card number available when depositing, withdrawing or borrowing money. The card will be required to obtain Medicare cash payments, to buy or sell property or even-can you believe it-to gain admission as an in-patient at a hospital. Not only will the hospital authorities require the card but also clause 53 (2) requires the hospital, as soon as possible, to notify the Health Insurance Commission of the card number. Primary producers will need to present the card before they can deal with marketing authorities or agencies. When the farmers realise this they will go off their heads. This will be an incredible bureaucratic problem for agents and farmers and, if I am any judge, we will see an increase in commission by agents to try to cope with the bureaucratic requirements in this clause of the Bill. In clause 43 (1), which concerns primary production, 'marketing authority' means a statutory marketing authority and 'produce agent' means an agent who is acting on behalf of a producer. The clause states: A marketing authority or produce agent shall not, or after the first relevant day, make to a person payment representing the proceeds, or part of ceeds, of sale of primary produce unless(a) the marketing authority or produce agent quires, or has at some previous time required pursuant to this sub-section, the production current Card of the person as at the time production . . . (c) the marketing authority or produce agent records, or has at some previous time recorded pursuant to this sub-section, the person's tralia Card number. Do honourable members know what the penalty is for non-compliance? It is $20,000. Mr MeGauran-How much?

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: Unknown
text: Because I did not have identification I was harassed. On occasions I wished that I had an Australia Card. The spoon-fed, silver-coated member would not know about that. On those occasions I would dearly have If liked to have had an Australia Card with my photograph because it would have protected my civil liberties. A lot of nonsense is talked about civil liberties. Members of the Opposition talk about their change of heart. I am all in favour of them changing their minds if they are wrong. In fact, they should all change their minds. Conin such a short time-six months on the to Damascus, when those opposite can go completely from one point of view to anotherto involves more than simply a change of mind. When I look into my wallet I find very little money but I find 14 credit cards. Every bit of plastic in my wallet has encoded little bits of information about me which are recorded somewhere. That is information over which I have no control. I know that this information is made available and used because last year I got a letter from American Express International Inc. saying: 'We have looked into you, Mr Campbell. We feel that you are the sort of citizen who should have one of our cards. We invite you to apply'. Being flattered I duly applied. The company eventually replied: 'We have checked out your credit rating. We will not give you a card'. I found this rather outrageous so I wrote back and said: 'I am incensed. I would like to know on what grounds you assess my credit rating'. I got no reply. There is no protection at all from these sorts of people. I am very conscious of civil liberties. There no doubt that within the Australia Card concept there is the possibility of some abuses. But this is a judgment a government has to make. The Opposition, having the purity of impotence, cannot do anything constructive. All it can do is haggle. Those opposite are not in a position to make the judgments that the Government has to. The Government has put in train protection mechanisms that will not subject me to such abuse. Let us consider other areas of civil liberties abuse about which nothing is done in this Parliament. I draw the attention of honourable members to changes that have been made to the Extradition Act, changes which run right over the civil liberties of people. Was there a murmur from those opposite? There was not. I spoke to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), one of the Opposition's more intellectual members and a member for whom, despite his rather pompous exterior, I have a very high regard. I could not even get him interested in the matter. I am very concerned about the grave injustices against civil liberties involved. As a result of those injustices two American citizens are languishing in gaol in Fremantle because they cannot get bail. That is an outrageous situation of which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) should not be proud. When the civil liberties of those gentlemen are diminished, the civil liberties of all of us are diminished and I am very conscious of this. I can remember when I was black banned by a large company for my opposition to it. I had no redress for that. It was able to circulate, by various means, allegations about me which effectively kept me out of employment for five months. As a result of that I was able to break that particular custom in respect of other people, but I did not even realise those bans existed in respect of me until very late in the piece. So civil liberties have to be guarded all the time. They are not guarded simply by legislation; they are embodied in the culture of a country. It is to our culture that we have to look for protection. I remember the scare tactics put out by the Opposition about the Bill of Rights. The Bill of Rights did not really offend anyone's civil liberties and neither did it particularly protect them. The truth is that the Bill of Rights was damn silly legislation. It did not embody the risks to society as honourable members opposite said it did. We have to go back to our culture because it is that which embodies our freedoms. It is is incumbent upon the Opposition to take a much more responsible view of this. I know that there are many people opposite who do not believe that this legislation carries the risks that they say it does and I wish that they would at least tone down some of the rhetoric they are using in this debate.

Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Title: Unknown
text: This proposed legislation to introduce a national identification system will be roundly condemned throughout the Australian community when people understand what it entails. There are four main reasons why the so-called Australia Card is not in the national interest. Firstly, it will enable governments to keep comprehensive records on every individual. The consequential misuse of that information will create many new forms of social and individual injustice. Secondly, the Australia Card is seen as a panacea to the inefficient administration of government. I contend that the efficient administration of government will only be attained by reintroducing market realities into the Public Service and by reducing the legislative burden. Introducing another card, another check or another administrative device will do nothing to improve the system. Thirdly, the Australia Card may have a popular appeal but it will not work. The card will be as easy to forge as a birth certificate, tax file number, Medicare card, driver's licence, health care card, marriage certificate, electoral roll listing, group certificate, passport or any other identification paper we already have in our society. In fact, this one-stop identification process is likely to reduce the number of checks which are a feature of our current system. Fourthly, at a time of economic war, as our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has termed it, why is the Government embarking on a scheme which is estimated to cost $759m over a period of 10 years? The statement of the financial impact of this legislation is laughable. There is no way that this card will not cost much more than it is worth in total community terms. Those people who attended the showing of Ray Bradbury's documentary Hasta Cuando about the Pinochet dictatorship in Chile would have been moved by his comment on the effect the national identification system had on Chile. Basically, he said it set up the building blocks for the development of a totalitarian state. A Chile policeman could apprehend a citizen, read off his number into a microphone on his lapel and have immediate access to total files maintained on the individual. If power corrupts, the counterpart is the Public Service's knowledge. Under this system the knowledge is always there just waiting for the Public Service interpreter to use it at will. The introduction of a universal ID card will provide government with an instantaneous data base on each individual. The argument for the introduction of the ID card is based on the premise that if one has nothing dishonest to hide, what is the problem. There is no doubt that for people who had anything to hide previously. things may become very difficult. As our Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has reassuringly told us: The key to the system is not the card itself but the generation of one number which will act as a linkage number, between for example Social Security and Tax records. I do not believe for a minute the linkage will end there. It will be across the spectrum of public service activities. A few examples can demonstrate the point. The Government does not need to be all-knowledgeable on the individual. Even if it is, the cold statistical base does not reflect the truth behind the individual. Individuals often hide the truth to avoid the prejudice of others. For instance, consider the job application form which questions whether the articulated applicant has a physical disability. For the plicant to answer yes would prejudice the applicheaper cation, even though he may be flilly able control the disability. Will applications for lic service jobs be cross-referenced against medigrading cal records? Will the Government also look for records on immigration and ethnic affairs and do spot checks on past income levels? The legislation, through the generation of one number, will act as a link between various departments. All the information will be on tap, whether or not it is a reasonable or accurate record of a person's activities. From reading clause 65 I would assume that this use of the Australia Card is quite possible, particularly with a similar minded bureaucracy throughout the Commonwealth Public Service. Under clause 43, marketing authorities and produce agents are required to see the Australia Card of any person to whom they make payment for primary produce. There is also a penalty if the marketing authority or the produce agents do not record the Australia Card number and provide the information when required by the Taxation Office. What happens if the information so supplied is incorrect? It is out of the hands of the farmer to rectify. He does not know what information has been transmitted about the financial transaction. The payment may be made then stopped for some reason. Is the record changed on the computer? I do not believe we can trust the Privacy Bill for adt".quate protection, or the Data Protection Agency which will be set up under this legislation. Incidentally, the Privacy Bill is based on Article XVII of the Bill of Rights which was so roundly condemned throughout the Australian community. I hope this proposal is not the alternative approach, to get all so-called rights passed in piecemeal fashion. I can imagine the unnecessary information conveyed through the central computer. Surely someone in this Government must stand back and say that the cure proposed is far worse than the disease. I thought that the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card made it clear that benefits in the area of taxation, welfare and immigration would be illusory. The main problem regarding taxation collection is the cash economy. The tax avoided through the cash economy was estimated to be between $8 billion and $30 billion in 1984-85. This card will do nothing to curb the cash economy. One widely reported statement by Mr Frank Costigan, QC, reads: I am bemused at the attempt to correct what are as problems in the community by a solution apsuch as the Australia Card . . . There are much and effective ways of coping with the problem to which arises from tax evasion and avoidance. pubCertain reforms in tax legislation and the upof the tax file number could achieve all the goals which are intended for the Australia Card. On pensions and social security, the De. partment of Social Security believes that the cost of the Australia Card would equal the benefits government received from the program. The Joint Select Committee concluded that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs should immediately transfer all its records from the manual system to a computer database. Simply put, the Department is running very inefficiently. Anyone who has any dealings with the Department would appreciate that. Some residents in my electorate have been waiting for more than a year for a decision. If they make an inquiry they are taught a lesson by being placed further back on the list. These are examples of how the departments can solve their own problems. As Roger Clarke said, the Government is using a jackhammer to crack a nut. If it started implementing reforms such as those mentioned in the conclusion of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union the need for this card would disappear. The Government is at pains to point out that it is not compulsory to apply for the Australia Card. But if a person does not have one, he will not be able to commence work, open a bank account, sell any primary produce, have a safe deposit box, claim for Medicare, purchase property or deal in shares. The little piece of plastic will be more invasive than the influenza virus of Australia's way of life. Whatever the Government says, this card is not voluntary; it is compulsory. The ominous nature of this legislation reminds us of George Orwell's 1984. The Government has introduced the card with a classic piece of double think. 'Voluntary' now means 'compulsory'. The other piece of double think is that it will not be necessary to carry the card on one's person. If the card is introduced it will be a landmark in Australia's history of the bureaucracy's dominance over the individual. The legislation provides the building blocks for a totalitarian state. It will take only one unscrupulous government to phase out all the privacy measures and we will be left with a system that knows more about our lives than we know or care to remember.

Smith, W. legitimacy of the state to demand that its citizens be accountable to it, and the reversal of the balance of power between the state and its citizens. On the outcome of this debate, should it go the way the Government wants, depends a new order in the relations between the state and its citizens. There is in our society a compelling need for the protection of privacy. It is under NA threat everywhere, especially from state agencies and commissions, which are given wide authoritarian powers to peer into the lives of our citiKatter, R. C. Nehl, G. B. zens, and especially from this Government, as has so irrefutably been demonstrated by the gross and deliberate invasion of privacy proposed by the Australia Card Bill. We on this side of the House have a fundamental and implacable resistance to this assault on our liberties. The Government has spoken of its commitment to the protection of privacy of Australians. It has broken this promise as easily and as carelessly as it has broken so many other promises. The issue is a simple one. We cannot have both privacy protection. and the identity card. Just as the Government praises its economic management while the' Australian economy lurches into an ever more hazardous state, so the Government speaks of the need to protect privacy while it legislates to destroy it. Government policy is not unlike the Soviet constitution. That constitution speaks of the guarantees of the rights of citizens, yet experience and history us how worthless those guarantees are. It is impossible to divorce the identity card from the Privacy Bill, because it is impossible to separate the Data Protection Agency, a wholly worthless agency set up under the identity card Bill, from the Privacy Bill. Some 20 of the 45 clauses of this Bill are exclusively concerned with the functions of the Data Protection Agency, because that agency is so closely and inextricably bound up with the identity card system. Whilst we endorse the need for legislation to protect privacy-a need which is compelling in our society-and whilst we generally endorse the privacy principles stated in the Privacy Bill, although those principles have been watered down from what they should have been by changes made to them by the Government, changes made in the form in which they appeared in a Law Reform Commission report, we will vote against this Bill. What the Government intends to do-I refer here to the identity card-is made possible only by computers. Computers have brought great benefits to our society. They have led immeasurably to society's capacity to store, retrieve, analyse and use an immense body of information. Computers have consigned to oblivion past record-keeping practices. In place of thousands of buildings and warehouses of files, innumerable man hours spent in finding files and cross-matching information we now have the databank and the computer terminal. In the last two decades we have seen a revolution in the storage and retrieval of information on which our society and all civilizations depend. There is, quite literally, no limit to the capability of computers as information storehouses. But for all its benefits, the computer age brings with it a great danger; just as the capability is revolutionary, so is the threat to privacy. The Government pays lipservice to the pressing need to guard against this danger. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his second reading speech on this Bill, said: In recent times there have been enormous developments in technology for processing information, providing immense opportunities for building up and using information on individuals. I repeat the words: 'building up and using information on individuals'. How right he is. He went on: More than anything else, the capacity of modern computers to search and process information offers the greatest potential for invasion of personal privacy by misuse. How right he is. We are going to have invasion tell of personal privacy by government edict. He went on: The greater the accumulations of personal information, the greater are the possibilities of inaccurate material being included amongst such information. Decisions based on wrong information are oppressive to the individual concerned and hinder efficient administration. No doubt they do, but the great problem is the invasion of privacy. That is the great danger. As many honourable members on the other side of this House know-and we all know there are honourable members on the other side of this House who believe this-this whole package of legislation which involves an identification for all adult Australians should never have been brought to this House. Even the prime architect of this massive intrusion into the privacy of Australians recognises, or pays lip-service to, the danger it poses. The Minister for Hea!t- (Dr Blewett), in his second reading speech on the Australia Card Bill, said: At the same time, this Government wishes to ensure that we maintain a proper balance between the need to protect the interests of the community, and the need to preserve the rights to privacy and civil liberty of the individual. The Government, by its words, recognises the dimension and the danger our society faces, yet it sets about to destroy the very privacy it says it is committed to uphold. The warnings against the road it is taking are many. The New South Wales Privacy Committee, the only permanent specialist body in this country devoted to privacy issues, representing both sides of politics and with a membership spanning a wide spectrum of our community, in its submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card of this Parliament said that it unanimously condemns the identity card. It concluded: That no convincing case has been made out for the proposed identification scheme. Its threat to privacy substantially outweighs any advantages it offers. Therefore the Privacy Committee recommends that the 'Australia Card' program be rejected by the Joint Select Committee. It said: In contrast to the levels of popular confusion about the card and its purposes, a large number of organisations, groups and individuals in addition to the Privacy Committee have indicated strong opposition to the ID card. Apart from numerous politicians from both sides of the political spectrum, opponents have included: Mr Justice Kirby; Frank Costigan QC; Professor Richard Harding, Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology; Professor Geoffrey DeQ Walker, Queensland University Law School; Mr Roger Clark, Australian National University; Professor Ron Johnston, Wollongong University; The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission; The NSW Council of Social Services; The Federal Council of the Liberal Party; The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Policy Committee of the Australian Labor Party; Where are the members of that Committee today? Have their views been heard? Another opponent is the Australian Society of Labor Lawyers. I commend its members for their views. Have their views been heard by this Government? I am taking this list directly from the report of the New South Wales Privacy Committee. When we look at those so-called protections we must look to the storehouse of information that will be generated about the lives of all adult Australians. So that the honourable member for Charlton, who has been interrupting so assiduously for the purpose of breaking up the debate, will understand what it is all about, a storehouse of information that necessarily follows from the impossibility of law abiding Australians acting satisfactorily and legally in our society without the identity card will be generated. An identity card will be a prerequisite of life in our society, First, there is the identification process. We have to understand these processes if we are to understand the futility of the so-called protections included in this Privacy Bill. Each Australian will have to satisfy the Government of his or her existence and to produce whatever information the Government reasonably thinks necessary for that purpose. One must go to a public servant and satisfy him that one has a right to be called by the name one was born under. The Government will have the power to tap into information kept on Australians by the Social Security Department and Veterans' Affairs Department and kept under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act, the Student Assistance Act, the Australian Citizenship Act, the Passports Act, and the Migration Act, all for the purpose of being satisfied about the identity of Australians. Secondly, for each card holder, details of names, addresses, sex, date and place of birth, residential address and other information will be stored on the identity card computer. Mr Robert Brown-I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sorry, but I must insist that the honourable member for North Sydney is not dealing with this legislation and it is not sufficient for him to make some passing reference to the Privacy Bills in order to justify continuing to debate issues which have been determined in this Parliament, namely, the Australia Card. The honourable member for North Sydney is not dealing with this legislation. He is dealing with legislation which has been passed by this Parliament. I ask you to draw to his attention the nature of the legislation and to insist that he deals with that legislation and not with something which has already been dealt with.

Title: PAIRS

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: PAIRS
text: Let me also remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the honourable member who has interrupted, that the Bill deals in 20odd clauses with the Data Protection Agency. The Data Protection Agency is set up under the Bill so grossly misnamed the Australia Card Bill. We have gone through the identification process. Secondly, for each card holder there is a storage of information on the main identity card computer. Thirdly, there is the extraordinary reporting system set up under the identity card Bill. This has to be considered when we are assessing the futility of this so-called privacy protection Bill. One must produce one's identity card to open an account with a bank, a building society, a credit union, a co-operative society, a sharebroker, a futures broker, 'a unit, property or cash management trust; to invest in government securities; to deposit money with a solicitor, or with a company; to purchase land; to deal with rural marketing authorities; to establish one's right to Medicare and social security benefits; to send money overseas and to establish one's right to payment of interest on money held in one's name with financial institutions. So even if the money is there when the Bill comes into effect one will need to prove one's identity by a card to withdraw one's own money. One will need it even to get a job. Fourthly, in all these cases the Government by its legislation intends that the unique identification number should be logged by the bank, by the building society, by the employer or by whomever else it is who must, under the identity card Act, and subject to heavy penalties, record the number. In most, if not all, cases, this information is to be available to the Commissioner of Taxation. The Department of Health and Department of Social Security also may have access to it. Fifthly, under the national computerised Births, Deaths and Marriages Register, information such as family composition, legitimation, adoption, marital status and, in many cases, religious affiliation could be retrieved. Honourable members should remember that that is the storehouse of information which will be generated. What will be the consequence? Computers can talk to one another. Compatible computers can retrieve information from each other. By this means and through the unique identification system with each card holder having his or her own unique number, this storehouse of information distributed through government departments across the whole of Australia can be accessed by one person sitting at a government computer terminal or, perhaps, a private computer terminal. A profile, unparalleled in detail, of the lives of card holders will be available to governments and to anyone else who can get access to the system. What are the protections? The Privacy Bill is claimed by the Attorney-General to regulate the collection, handling and use by the Commonwealth departments and agencies of information about individuals so as to provide them with a level of privacy protection that is consistent with efficient government administration. I emphasise the words 'consistent with efficient government administration'. The Bill states 11 principles called information privacy principles. The idea is said to be to confer some measure of protection for individuals against governments but the protections are as worthless as the Data Protection Agency set up under the Australia Card Bill which has such a major role in the Privacy Bill. They are worthless for the following reasons. First and fundamentally, the whole structure of the legislative package is such that the right to privacy of individual Australians is deeply infringed. That is the underlying philosophy and the direct legal intent of what the Government is doing. The so-called protections come into effect only after this infringement has lawfully taken place. In no way does it diminish this infringement or qualify it. The Government gave the game away in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General when he said there will be 'a level of privacy protection that is consistent efficient government administration'. We know how many liberties have been lost through the beguiling argument that we need efficient administration. The next reason why these protections are worthless is that the Data Protection Agency does not have direct control over the contents of the Register, the way it is used or the way information is relayed among government departments. Third, there are literally thousands of government servants who have access to the computer terminals which can call up information about individuals from agencies throughout Australia. All these are linked by the identity card number. How will it be possible for any agency, regardless of how many thousands of public servants work for it, to monitor access to this unique and extraordinary bank of information on the lives of Australians? How is it possible to prevent leaks and unauthorised usage? All of our experience of leaked confidential information from government departments tells us that it is not possible. Who will guard the guardians? Fourth, the Data Protection Agency is hamstrung in its functions. It is bound by information privacy principles and the weakness in those principles is brought about by some of the changes made to them by this Government. Fifth, it appears that the Government has not heard of computer hackers. It is notorious that even the most secure systems have been penetrated. I give two very brief examples taken from the Australian Accountant of February 1986. It recorded a case in America in which children broke into a cancer research clinic over the weekend. They were able to collect all user IDs and passwords. They wanted to break in so that they could get some computer time. These were children breaking in. Let us take a case in this country. In Melbourne a bank electronic funds transfer system was exploited by a youth to withdraw $40,000. He had worked out the means to enter the system, set up a bogus account and made his withdrawal at a time when he knew the system to be vulnerable because of a changeover of equipment. We are talking here about highly secure systems. We know that even the most secure systems can be penetrated. This system will contain information about the lives of just about every adult Australian, every permanent resident in this country over the age of 16. Does anybody think that that system will be secure? Of course no one does. Of course one knows this talk about security is as bogus as the with speech made about privacy by the Minister for Health and his concern about maintaining some sort of balance of power between the Government and individuals. I conclude by saying that we have made it plain that we support the need for privacy legislation. What the Government has done makes it very clear how important strong privacy legislation is. But this Bill is a side issue. The real issue is the Bill to which it is tied-the Australia Card Bill. Members of this Government have run like a collection of frightened rats on the fringe benefits tax. We will see them run again on this Bill. We will take this argument around the country. We will tell Australians what is involved. We will make them understand. There will be an upsurge of opinion against this Bill just as there was an upsurge of opinion against the Bill of Rights and the fringe benefits tax. Then we will see the strength of the Government's resolution. We all know how strong its resolution was when it came under political pressure as a consequence of the fringe benefits tax. We will see the Prime Minister consult the polls and the tea leaves to try to get himself off the political hook of this Bill on which he has managed to impale himself.

Title: PAIRS
text: Today we are dealing with the Privacy Bill 1986. That would not have been clear at all from the speech of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). However, it is good that a Party like the Liberal Party, which introduced conscription, which sent young men to Vietnam against their will to fight and die, is now suddenly allegedly finding principles and issues that it wishes to put before the people on civil liberties. They were not doing very much in the Fraser years when there were appalling reports by the Commissioner of Taxation about fraud and tax cheating. Frank Costigan was called in and did a great job in pointing out that payment of tax became optional under the Liberal-National Party Government. The speech of the honourable member for North Sydney only proves how divided the coalition in Opposition is and how much tension and confusion the Liberal Party and the National Party display on this important issue of the Australia Card. This legislation works on the enormous contribution of the Law Reform Commissioner, Mr Justice Michael Kirby, who evolved the information privacy principles before the House today and which will become law. As honourable members can see, there are no penalties in the legislation. The provision is that there will be reports to Parliament. Some of the things that the honourable member for North Sydney said are true. Mistakes are made with computers. I had a telephone call this week at my office from a person in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The person apologised profusely. There was a hiccup in the computer and a good friend of mine in Concord received a letter saying that his veterans' affairs pension had stopped because he was dead. He was somewhat surprised to receive that letter. However he has a good sense of humour and he will not mind. Such things do happen. In my experience public servants work very hard and are very honourable people. Enormous numbers of public servants not just the ones mentioned by the honourable member for North Sydney but thousands of people in the Australian Taxation Office have access to confidential taxation records, records in which taxpayers clare all their sources of income be they legal illegal. These people know what income is availing able and have access to the records. They maintain confidentiality. Why should the public servants who administer the Australia Card denly reveal this information or disclose it lawfully? Why should there be such a hoo-ha and a hullabaloo about it? The honourable member for North Sydney really descended into the farcical when he talked about the prospect of people's religious affilianation tions suddenly being retrieved by somebody pressing a button. That is just nonsense. If is the strength of the argument that the Liberal and National Parties put up against the Privacy Bill and the Australia Card that is a joke. Many benefits will come from the introduction of the Australia Card. As speakers on the Government side said ad infinitum in that debate this is not a card that one carries like a Medicare card or a credit card. It will be needed for only limited purposes. As Frank Costigan insisted, this country must tighten procedures for opening bank accounts and upgrade the operation of banking facilities. One of the reasons for having an Australia Card is to operate a bank account. Another is to obtain a government payment. It is essential that people who obtain any government payments, be they pensions or unemployment benefits, obtain them legally. The vast majority of Australians who obtain unemployment benefits or who have to live on the pension or the supporting parents' benefit receive those payments legitimately and properly. This card will ensure that a person seeking the benefit is a real person and that the transaction is not fraudulent. It is a sensible and efficient way to ensure that the whole system is properly organised and managed. It is possible to check every person weekly to ensure that they are still in need of unemployment benefit, the pension or the supporting parents benefit and that they are not working, but that would be an extraordinary financial undertaking. It would require inspectors and supervisors and it would be very intrusive. It would offend the civil liberties of all if officers went out to homes, knocked on doors, and said 'Are you still here?' or 'Why weren't you here when I called yesterday to check whether you are still unemployed?'. A person who is unemployed is supposed to be out and about looking for work. I think the Australia Card is a tremendous decompromise. When I initially heard the proposal or I opposed it automatically. With my legal trainand background I thought it was terrible. - ut I changed my mind whe-, over a long penod, I read the. rep-rt- and hstened to the arsud_,gumcnts about It wlthm the Labor Party, the un-' Lab-r Government,. the Caucus. and the community. After - alkmg to constItuc:;nts I even started a group. m my area of people who were opposed to the Idea of an ID card. Those people said to me eventually: 'Why did you change your mind?'. I replied that I did not agree with our being robbed by people who fraudulently came into the country as tourists and worked, that people who got payments illegally and people who defrauded all the Government departments-people who set out blatantly to deceive by obtaining a number of driver's licences and putting themselves on the dole and, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said, receiving enormous fraudulent payments. Australians pay a lot of tax but they do believe that there should be a system which at least tries to make the social welfare segment of the Government's expenditure fair and honest. I believe it will be a great step forward in that regard. The earliest moves in Australia to do something about privacy were taken in New South Wales by the late John Maddison, a former Minister of Justice in a Liberal government, who established the New South Wales Privacy Committee. I pay great tribute to John as he was a wonderful Australian who saw the need for privacy legislation. The New South Wales Privacy Committee is essentially an advisory body that looks at complaints and makes reports to Parliament. For years and years there have been complaints about the sale of names of debtors in courts and many of these procedures have been endorsed by governments. From time to time the question of privacy comes into the public arena. Another debate which floated around and which is terribly important is the issue of spent tions-people who have some conviction in their past, perhaps as a student peccadillo, as Mr Justice Fullagar referred to one student whose case he dealt with in the High Court of Australia. A man who I went through law school with, when being admitted to practice, had to disclose that he had been convicted of being drunk in Hyde Park. He was terribly embarrassed about this and I did not blame him because it had happened years before. But people have these things with them for the rest of their lives. Police and employers are very reluctant to allow people not to mention a previous conviction. This is part of the confidentiality and privacy requirements. I believe that the information privacy principles we are establishing today, which will bring Australia into line with the rest of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations, will do something to work on this notion of spent convictions to strike some sort of balance between the needs of the police and of employers to know the full details of one's past and at the same time save people from humiliation for the whole of their lives. The Privacy Bill being debated fits in and dovetails with the Freedom of Information Act introduced in 1982. I pay tribute to the previous Government for bringing that legislation in, particularly the late Senator Missen, who pushed for this legislation. It is extremely significant legislation because similar legislation does not apply in any of the States. It is quite pioneering as it gives individuals access to information prepared and collected at government expense. In Part IV are various categories of exempt documents. All the legal professional privileges that have come from the Courts of Chancery over the years which ensure that the solicitor-client relationship will prevent production of documents are recognised in Part IV. Documents connected with a client approaching a solicitor or barrister for advice are always privileged. The freedom of information legislation also talks about the amendment of personal records, so there is a close relationship between the two. Of course, the introduction of the Australia Card necessitated the introduction of this privacy legislation. I want to touch on other matters that this legislation will affect. One matter which has always annoyed me, not only in this Parliament but also in a State parliament in which I served, is the practice of Ministers-certainly not the Minister at the table, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-of all parties replying to memconvic- bers of parliament when a member may have written five or six letters to that Minister detailing problems of constituents and inevitably saying: 'I reply to your letter on behalf of Mrs Smith, Mrs O'Brien, Mrs Jones, Mrs Maddern and Mrs Brown'. I believe this is a total breach of privacy and confidentiality. I believe this legislation before the House to introduce information privacy principles will stop this practice. Constituents become quite annoyed because they do not want to know who else has written to a member and they do not want other people to know that they have written to a member about some issue. Similarly, if a constitilent writes to me and to a Minister, the Minister will often reply: 'Here is the letter I have sent to the constituent. Thank you.' I believe that is probably outlawed or proscribed by this legislation because a Minister has no right to release a letter he has sent to a constituent. Even if a constituent writes in similar terms, the Minister should observe the niceties of this legislation, and I believe this is an important milestone in parliamentary and ministerial representations. In accordance with this legislation, government departments will have to look at all the information they collect. Any Australian who comes back from overseas has to fill out an immigration form as soon as he comes into Australia under the headings 'Citizenship' and then 'Country of Birth'. Why should any government department be allowed to ask where a person was born? A person is either an Australian or a non-Australian, according to the Migration Act. Why should any government department want to know whether a person was born in England, Ireland, Lebanon or Poland? Is it some sort of signal that if a person was born in a foreign country the authorities should search his baggage all the more? I think it is disgraceful. I have always objected to many of these questions that government departments place on forms. I think that Immigration, Customs and all these government departments must review the information they require individuals to declare on forms and certificates. I again make the point that the honourable member for North Sydney is quite wrong when he says that, by pressing a button, a government officer can find out a person's religious affiliation. That is one question that many people do not answer in a census as it is one question that is optional, yet he says that we will have a situation where a person's religious affiliation can be sourced. The depth of the Opposition's argument against this Bill and the Australia Card is nonsense. Other matters I did want to touch on today relate to the problems of the correction of information which is wrongly recorded. We all hear, as members of parliament, some horrendous stories of people who have had a default judgment entered against them by mistake or who at the last minute come to some arrangement with their creditors but find that credit agencies have their name blacklisted and they cannot obtain a loan or credit. As recently as yesterday I talked and wrote to the Attorney-General about a constituent who had a default judgment entered against him and who then got into a number of problems with other creditors. An alderman of Drummoyne Council, in my area, Alderman Tredwell, has raised the matter with me and with the State member for Drummoyne, who has raised it in the New South Wales Parliament. Credit agencies wrongly recorded indebtedness against this alderman and he had great trouble obtaining loans to finance the purchase of a new home. He had no redress. He had no way in which he could sort out the whole question of his privacy, his good name and his credit worthiness. I pay tribute to Mr Justice Kirby, an old friend of mine, who has worked very hard on the privacy area through the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations. He is probably the world authority on privacy. He has done a great job.

I am sure he is a very sensible man and he would see that the problems that he may envisage are far outweighed by the need to allow the Government to protect the revenue, to protect the payments made from the hard earned funds of taxpayers who pay tax through the pay as you earn system every week with no way of avoiding tax. The money is taken out at source. These people do not want to see their money fraudulently taken by illegal immigrants who are working in Australia, perhaps receiving unemployment benefits or social security benefits. Taxpayers do not want to see people fraudulently getting multiple dole cheques or avoiding paying tax by working under other names or by not paying the interest on bank accounts or other investments. It is a fair enough argument that people should see that the tax system is not bleeding, that it is getting in the revenue and that it is properly working. Australia is a great country with a great future. As I have said, the three Bills being considered today are supplementary. This important legislation is the first set of guidelines in any Australian parliament to lay down the rules to protect privacy. In New South Wales and Queensland there are privacy committees but they are both only advisory. The various clauses of the Bills which set forth the principles for privacy should be supported by the Hous-. Speaker: Mr SMITH
Title: PAIRS
text: 1 understood the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) to have stated that his initial reactions, because of his legal training, were to oppose the Australia Card Bill. If he had followed those initial reactions he would now find himself on the same side as his friend Mr Justice Kirby. The purpose of the Privacy Bill 1986 is to regulate the collection, handling and use by Commonwealth departments and agencies of information about individuals. The aim is to provide privacy protection that is, in the words of the Attorney General (Mr Lionel Bowen), 'consistent with efficient government administration'. That is stated in the second reading speech. One might well ask: What does this mean? Efficiency is a little like peace; one can define it in many different ways. Many things have been done by governments in the name of efficiency. It is now an accepted truism that with the capacity of new generation computers and information processing capabilities there exists the greatest tial for the invasion of personal privacy by misuse. The ever-increasing role of governments at all levels, by the provision of services and the accumulation of information, is a fact that is well known to every thinking citizen. Whether this continual march forward by government into the life of the citizen is good or not is indeed a broader debate. Suffice it to say that my view is that the rapidity of the growth of government in its information seeking and retrieval capabilities is one of the most unhealthy trends of the development of the modern state. This Bill adopts the Australian Law Reform Commission draft legislation and also draws on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development guidelines on privacy. It is my view that there are features of the proposed legislation which should be endorsed. In general terms, the information privacy principles deserve support. There are 11 principles. They refer to things such as, in No.1, the manner and purpose of collection of personal information. No. 3 deals with the solicitation of personal information generally. I highlight that No. 11 refers to the limits on disclosure of personal information solicited from information subjects. This is a very important provision because who gets what information is a basic question. It illustrates the extreme difficulty in formulating the legislation. Honourable members will see this if they look at that principle carefully. However, there is no doubt in my mind that there is a compelling need for privacy legislation. Whilst government activity is the focus-such as in social security, education, taxation and health and so on-we should not forget the ever increasing reach of statutory authorities such as the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Bureau gives me some concern, not necessarily through its collection of census information but through other surveys, that it is increasingly undertaking to gather further information. Also, the relationship of databases of government being used by political parties, businesses or unions requires further study. After all, as we all know in this place, a very basic political tool is a good mailing list. The sophistication of the new marketing techniques targeted to certain groups is based on personal data analysis. The wrongful use of government personal data is apparent for even the most innocent to see. 'Personal information' is very widely defined in the Bill to include anything-fact, true, false or opinion, although unrecorded conversation is not covered. Breaches potenof the principles are to be overviewed by the Data Protection Agency. Where there is a failure to satisfy an alleged breach of privacy by conciliation the next step is to report it to the Minister. Injunctive relief would be available as it is now. The sanction for a breach of privacy is in reality a bit of a paper tiger. It leaves one feeling that the elaborate mechanisms set up are but an expression of a desire for an ideal guard to privacy which relies more on the good sense of the information collector than anything else. I come back to my earlier observation: The only sure way to ensure privacy of the individual from the abuse by government is not to collect so much information in the first place. The demands of the Australian Taxation Office for information on the basis 'we may need it' seems a spurious argument. It is a waste of time, money and effort and an intrusion of the very worse type. I commend to all honourable members the recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure on this very subject. Privacy protection demands a balance between the rights of individuals and the needs of the state. I underline the word 'needs'. This is where I part company from the Government, on the question of needs. The Australia Card Bill is an integral part of the privacy legislation, or vice versa. This was pointed out in relation to clause 21. Privacy is a basic premise in our libenil democracy. It is eloquently described as 'a vulnerable, fragile and essential freedom'. It is 'a defence against the tyranny of the temporary majority'. That is what this Government is, a temporary majority. It has hitched its privacy principles to the biggest, most intrusive invasion of basic privacy of the individual in this country's history in a way that any thinking person must view with deep concern. The Australia Card package must be opposed in its entirety. Part only, such as this Bill, cannot be passed. The splitting of the Data Protection Agency functions between the two Bills-Privacy and Australia Card-is a cynical, blatant attempt to use the very just and sensible privacy principles as a mechanism to garner support for this odious Australia Card. It is a tactic of parliamentary draftsmanship unworthy of the Attorney. The data bank information to be gathered by the Australia Card Bill is awesome in its scope. People deserve protection from it and from its wrongful use. The basic question though is: Do we need it? T):le answer is clearly no. The honourable member for Lowe referred to Mr Justice Kirby. He is an articulate and learned former Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission and is respected by all in the community. He issued a warning on this card which is worth remembering. He said: Carrying the card will be obligatory in due course of time. And producing it will become commonplace and, ultimately, in response to some outrage, obligatory. In the space of a few years, an important principle that marks off the intrusion of officialdom into our lives could be demolished. And the 'intrusion might not just be physical. It might go on behind the scenes-intrusion into the data profile where more and more decisions affecting the subject may be made without the knowledge of the data subject. This is a warning from the man who spent over 10 years looking solely at law reform, a man who was described some minutes ago by the honourable member for Lowe as a world authority on privacy. His statement calls for privacy protection, to be sure, but it is far more fundamental. It is a statement that says: 'Do not establish a framework that will require a necessary protection mechanism, for any such mechanism will be imperfect'. The very best protection is not to proceed. It is a matter of needs: As I said, we do not need the card. There are alternatives. If one looks at the social security system that has been touted as a reason that we need the ID card

Speaker: Mr SMITH
Title: PAIRS
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I was saying-and I am aware of your warning-in regard to the social security situation, it has been argued that we ought to proceed with the legislation that has just been passed on the basis that we need to be able to do away with what has been referred to as social security fraud. My point is that surely it would be better to have stricter identification requirements for the 2.8 million clients of the Department of Social Security, rather than put in place a system that will affect 16 million Australians. If one looks at taxation administration, which has also been a basis for wanting to proceed with the Australia Card, there is scope for administrative efficiency improvements. The report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, which was released recently, amply outlined that these improvements could be achieved. It is also interesting that the Expenditure Committee is about to embark on an inquiry into another aspect of taxation administration. I think that that report will have some interesting proposals for honourable members to contemplate. The social implications of this momentous step will not be felt for many years. The computer matching capability is frightening. The Australian Computer Society, condemning the card proposals, stated: Computer matching brings together vast amounts of data about each individual, which was collected by different organisations for quite different purposes and with varying degrees of care and accuracy. The scope for misunderstanding and misinterpretation of merged data is enormous. There is also, of course, the problem of multiple access through computer terminals. My point is that privacy is threatened as never before. The Privacy Bill will not protect the citizen from the intrusion that the ID card will bring. The Government seeks to protect privacy with this Bill, while at the same time legislating to destroy it with the Australia Card Bill. This is a sad day for individual liberty and the privacy of the citizen. This Bill, unfortunately, must be opposed. The basic privacy principles, whilst they are in themselves good, are totally integrated into the Data Protection Agency aspects of this Bill and also the Bill that has just been passed, the Australia Card Bill. I find it sad that I must oppose those principles, but because of the way in which the legislation has been drafted-the cynical approach to the drafting-and the total integration of the whole package, we have no choice but to oppose it.
